Question: 1265:Why does the Qur’an use the words "We" or "Us" to describe Allah when He is one?
 
 
 Answer: The Lord sometimes refers to Himself in the singular, by name or by use of a pronoun, and sometimes by use of the plural, as in the phrase: 'Verily, We have given you a manifest victory" (48:1) and other similar phrases. 
 
 However, God never refers to Himself by use of the dual, because the plural refers to the respect that He deserves, and may refer to His names and attributes, whereas the dual refers to a specific number (and nothing else), and He is far above that. 
 
 When God says in the Qur'an "Verily We" and "We", it is for respect and glorification, not to indicate plurality of numbers. If a verse of this type is causing confusion, it is essential to refer to the clear, unambiguous verses for clarification such as:
 
 "And your god is One God, there is none who has the right to be worshipped but He, the Most Beneficent, the Most Merciful" (2:163)

 Appendix - guide to translation...
 
 A. Gender-related renderings of Biblical language which we affirm:
 
 1. The generic use of ?he, him, his, himself? should be employed to translate generic 3rd person masculine singular pronouns in Hebrew, Aramaic and Greek. However, substantival participles such as ho pisteuon can often be rendered in inclusive ways, such as ?the one who believes? rather than ?he who believes.?
 
 2. Person and number should be retained in translation so that singulars are not changed to plurals and third person statements are not changed to second or first person statements, with only rare exceptions required in unusual cases.
 
 3. ?Man? should ordinarily be used to designate the human race, for example in Genesis 1:26-27; 5:2; Ezekiel 29:11; and John 2:25.
 
 4. Hebrew Ðsh should ordinarily be translated ?man? and ?men,? and Greek anÂr should almost always be so translated.
 
 5. In many cases, anthrÜpoi refers to people in general, and can be translated ?people? rather than ?men.? The singular anthrÜpos should ordinarily be translated ?man? when it refers to a male human being.
 
 6. Indefinite pronouns such as tis can be translated ?anyone? rather than ?any man.?
 
 7. In many cases, pronouns such as oudeis can be translated ?no one? rather than ?no man.?
 
 8. When pas is used as a substantive it can be translated with terms such as ?all people? or ?everyone.?

 Apathy << What gender is God? The question is: In the Bible and the Koran, God is always referred to as Him or He (except in the first of Genesis where God is referred to as "We" and "Our"). God is always given Father-like attributes. Why would God require a gender? . . . So, why is God male?

 
 First off, it is physically impossible for creation to contain God. He is infinite, and creation is not. David writes of God Almighty, "But will God indeed dwell on the earth? Behold, heaven and the highest heaven cannot contain You, how much less this house which I have built!" 1Kings 8:27. We are living within a temporal creation governed by the limitations of time and space. Everything that has ever occurred inside this bubble of creation, and everything that shall happen, took place in the flash of a single instant to Him. All of these things take place within creation over billions and billions of years from our perspective. Therefore, if we could look beyond the veil of time and space to actually see God Almighty, then all we would see is His stare; as if God had His picture taken. It is through His "His eternal power and divine nature" (Rom. 1:20) that He can 'dwell in' His Three Witnesses. 
 
 God of Genesis 1 is plural, because the Father (Spirit), Son (blood) and Holy Spirit (water) (from Matt. 28:19) were working in unison. The Three that bear witness, after all, "are into the One" (1John 5:8). "For there are three that testify: the Spirit and the water and the blood; and the three are into the One." 1John 5:7+8. Take careful note that of Christ it is said, "He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation." Col. 1:15. He is the 'image' of God Almighty from outside of time and space in that all Three are present 'in' Christ. Christ said, "Believe Me that I am in the Father and the Father is in Me." John 11:14. And Scripture says, "Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan . . ." Luke 4:1. And lastly, Scripture says, ". . . that God was in Christ reconciling the world to Himself . . ." 2Cor. 5:19. Our God that was in Christ reconciling creation to Himself is God Almighty from outside time and space. 
 
 There is no such thing as male of female in the spirit. Nor do those human attributes exist 'in Christ.' As it is written, "There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free man, there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus." Gal. 3:28. Christ says, "For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven." Matt. 22:30. 
 
 The answers to these questions lie in the relationship of the Three Witnesses (Father, Son and Holy Spirit) of The Almighty who is beyond this realm of time, and how the principles that govern those relationships are depicted in the 'image' of everything else in creation. "Then God said, "Let Us make man in Our image, according to Our likeness . . . God created man in His own image, in the image of God He created him; male and female He created them." Gen. 1:26 +27. Note that Elohim is creating His 'sixth day' male and female with the command to, "Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth . . ." Gen. 1:28. Here we also see three witnesses of male (spirit), female (water), and their seed (blood). This is NOT Adam who was formed on the seventh day by "YHVH Elohim' (the Lord God). The Lord of this Sabbath day (we are still in the seventh day) is our Lord Jesus Christ. "For the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath." Matt. 12:8. He is the Lord God of the OT. 
 
 To visualize this formula, draw two circles on a piece of paper that overlap. Note that two circles now make up three parts, and that the central part is 'begotten' from the joining of the other two. Label one side "spirit," the other side "water," and the central part "blood." The best picture I can find is here: 
 
 http://www.vb-helper.com/vbgp/ray_spheres1.jpg
 
 This triune relationship can be seen in the heavens (spirit), earth (water) and heaven (blood), in the temple/tabernacle with the Holy of Holies (spirit), Court (water) and Holy Place (blood); and within man himself in his spirit (spirit), body (water) and soul (blood). In each case, when the spirit and water witnesses are brought together, the third (blood; central part) witness is 'begotten,' by the overlapping of the other two. This is the seen in the case of Adam himself, when the breath of life (spirit) was joined with the dust of the ground (body; water), "and man 'became' a living being (soul)." Gen. 2:7. BTW, today we are born in the image of fallen Adam. The Lord God was able to take Eve out of Adam (with the seed), because he was formed with all three witnesses into the one. That form is what we aspire to in our 'incorruptible' (1Cor. 15:53) form. "For this perishable must put on the imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality." 
 
 Christ is called the 'only begotten from the Father' (John 1:14), because He came to exist 'within time and space' from the joining of the Father (spirit sphere) and the Holy Spirit (water sphere); which correspond to His Sprit and His Body. So as a man is three (spirit, body and soul) and yet is one, God within creation is also Three (Father, Son and Holy Spirit) and yet is One God. Since the 'male' holds the position of the 'spirit' in the equation, then the personality of the Spirit side is that of a Father and masculine. "God is spirit, and those who worship Him must worship in spirit and truth." John 4:24. For all the above to be true, then God must represent Himself to us using the male gender. For Him to express Himself in any other way would be inconsistent with everything He teaches through His Word. 
 
 God bless,
 
 Terral
